comment: Controls the center and is usually followed by 2. c4.
The Queen's Gambit. It is not a true gambit because White can eventually win back the pawn if Black plays 1... dxc4
Declining the gambit and defending the center.
Developing and putting pressure on the center.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6
comment: Defending the center.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3
comment: Developing.

comment: Pinning the knight to the queen.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. Bg5 Be7
comment: Breaking the pin.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 b6
comment: It would have been better to castle first.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 b6 7. cxd5
comment: If now 7... exd5 then 8. Bb5 Bb7 9. Ne5 (Threatening 10. Bxf6 Bxf6 11. Bxd7+) 0-0 10. Bc6 Bxc6 11.Nxc6 and White has a strong postion.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 b6 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Nxd5
comment: If 8... Bxg5 then 9. Nxc7+ Qxc7 10.Nxg5 and White is a pawn ahead.

comment: White now has the more active pieces and a chance to bring the rook into action on the c file.

comment: Getting the king out of the center and bringing the rook into play.
